Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The Mother Superior has asked the nun to lead a series of daily reflections for the entire community during an upcoming retreat.
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my laptop screen illuminating the quiet convent room. Slack notifications pinged insistently—reminders that the design documents for our new app feature were due by the end of the week. Product managers and engineers from other teams were waiting for my technical input, and I knew any delay would hold up the entire project. My mind raced with architecture diagrams and user flows, but my heart was heavy with another responsibility. Earlier that day, Mother Superior had gently asked me to lead daily reflections for the upcoming retreat, a role that required deep spiritual study and prayerful preparation. The community looked to me for guidance, expecting thoughtful meditations that would nourish their souls. I felt torn, pulled between the urgent demands of my team and the sacred trust of my sisters. As I stared at the blinking cursor, I wondered how I could possibly meet both expectations, my mind a battleground between code and contemplation.
